verses.text: If I speak in the tongues of men and of angels, but have not love, I am only a noisy gong or a clanging cymbal.
verses.comment: Paul stresses that even speaking miraculous languages is worthless without true love. This grounds all spiritual gifts in love, reflecting Christ Himself as the perfect model of love (see John 13:34).

verses.text: And if I have prophecy, and understand all mysteries and all knowledge, and if I have all faith, enough to move mountains, but do not have love, I am nothing.
verses.comment: Even the greatest spiritual insight or mountain-moving faith is empty without love. Love is the foundation of the Christian life and virtue, superseding even the most impressive spiritual gifts.

verses.text: And if I give away all I have to feed the poor, and if I hand over my body to be burned, but have not love, I gain nothing.
verses.comment: Self-sacrifice, even in martyrdom or charity, must be motivated by genuine love. Without it, acts of giving or suffering are spiritually empty.

verses.text: Love is patient and kind; love does not envy, it does not boast, it is not arrogant,
verses.comment: Here, love is described through its virtues—patience and kindness—and by the absence of vices. This reflects the fruit of the Spirit (see Galatians 5:22).

verses.text: it does not act dishonorably, it does not seek its own interest, it is not easily angered, it keeps no record of wrongs.
verses.comment: True love is selfless and forgiving, mirroring how Christ teaches us to forgive as we have been forgiven. There is an implicit call to ongoing reconciliation and unity among believers.

verses.text: Love does not rejoice in unrighteousness, but rejoices with the truth.
verses.comment: Love is bound to the truth, as Christ calls Himself 'the Truth' (John 14:6). This points to the inseparable link between authentic charity and truth.

verses.text: It bears all things, believes all things, hopes all things, endures all things.
verses.comment: Love perseveres and hopes unfailingly, echoing Christ’s ultimate endurance on the Cross out of love (see Hebrews 12:2–3).

verses.text: Love never fails. But prophecies will pass away, tongues will cease, knowledge will vanish.
verses.comment: Spirit-given gifts are for this age, but love is everlasting. This affirms love as the greatest, most enduring spiritual reality, continuing into eternity.

verses.text: For we know in part and we prophesy in part,
verses.comment: Human knowledge and prophecy are limited; in this life, believers only grasp a portion of the fullness that will be revealed in eternity.

verses.text: but when what is complete comes, what is partial will pass away.
verses.comment: This verse points forward to the perfect knowledge that awaits in the future, beyond the partial understanding of the current age. The Church awaits this fulfillment when Christ returns.

verses.text: When I was a child, I spoke like a child, thought like a child, reasoned like a child. When I became a man, I put away childish things.
verses.comment: Paul uses maturity as a metaphor for spiritual growth: while the Church on earth is growing, fullness will only be reached in the age to come.

verses.text: For now we see in a mirror dimly, but then face to face. Now I know in part; then I will know fully, even as I am fully known.
verses.comment: The promise of seeing 'face to face' points to the ultimate union with God. Early Christians understood this as a reference to the direct, unmediated vision of God in glory — the ultimate fulfillment of relationship with Him.

verses.text: Now these three remain: faith, hope, and love — but the greatest of these is love.
verses.comment: Faith, hope, and love are the foundational virtues. Yet love is the highest because it alone continues eternally, perfecting and completing the other two (see Romans 5:5).
